tn.text: See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_poetry]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]]

tn.ref: In what direction has your beloved gone
tn.text: "Which way did your beloved go"
See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:sng:01:08|1:8]].

tn.ref: so that we may seek him with you
tn.text: AT: "Tell us, so that we can look for him with you." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: My beloved has gone down to his garden
tn.text: See the explanation of this image in [[:en:bible:notes:sng:05:01|5:1]].

See how you translated "beds of spices" in [[:en:bible:notes:sng:05:13|5:13]]. The beloved has come to enjoy the physical attractions of the woman which are wonderful like spices. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: to graze in the garden and to gather lilies
tn.text: The woman uses these images to indicate that her beloved is delighting in her. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
See how you translated "he grazes" in [[:en:bible:notes:sng:02:16|2:16]].
"to pick lilies"
See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:sng:02:16|2:16]].

tn.ref: I am my beloved's, and my beloved is mine
tn.text: See how you translated "My beloved is mine, and I am his" in [[:en:bible:notes:sng:02:16|2:16]].

tn.ref: he grazes among the lilies with pleasure
tn.text: See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:sng:02:16|2:16]].
Here begins Part Five of the book

tn.ref: as beautiful as Tirzah, my love, as lovely as Jerusalem
tn.text: The lover compares the woman's beauty and pleasantness with beautiful and pleasant cities. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:sng:01:05|1:5]].

tn.ref: as awe-inspiring as an army with its banners
tn.text: inspiring as an army with its banners** - The beauty of the woman is so powerful that it makes the lover feel helpless, as if an army were approaching him.
The lover continues to praise the woman.
"terrify me." The eyes of the woman are so beautiful that it makes the lover feel overwhelmed and afraid because he cannot resist their power.

tn.ref: Your hair ... from the slopes of Mount Gilead
tn.text: See how you translated "Your hair ... from Mount Gilead" in [[:en:bible:notes:sng:04:01|4:1]].
The lover continues to praise the woman.

tn.ref: Your cheeks are like pomegranate halves behind your veil
tn.text: See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:sng:04:03|4:3]].

tn.ref: There are sixty queens, eighty concubines
tn.text: "There are 60 queens, 80 concubines." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
The words, "without number" means that no one can count them. AT: "multitudes of young women" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
See how you translated "my dove, my undefiled one" in [[:en:bible:notes:sng:05:02|5:2]].
"is unique" or "is one of a kind." The lover is contrasting the woman with all the other women. Although there are very many excellent women, this woman stands out as unique among the rest.

tn.ref: she is the special daughter of her mother
tn.text: "she is her mother's unique daughter" or "she is her mother's daughter that is one of a kind"
"the woman who gave birth to her." This phrase refers to her mother.
"and declared that things had gone especially well for her" or "said that she was fortunate"
What the queens and the concubines said about the young woman. However, some versions think that the woman's lover is speaking in this verse also.

tn.ref: Who is this who appears like the dawn
tn.text: They are using this question to say that they think the young woman is amazing. AT: "This is an amazing woman! She comes into view like the dawn." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

AT: "she comes into view like the dawn." The lover uses this image to say that the woman is as beautiful and as majestic as the dawn when it begins to shine. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: as awe-inspiring as an army with its banners
tn.text: inspiring as an army with its banners** - The beauty of the woman is so powerful that it makes the other women feel helpless, as if an army were approaching them. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:sng:06:04|6:4]].
The lover finishes speaking to himself.
See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:sng:04:12|4:13]].
"young plants" or "new shoots"
"had grown their buds." Buds are the small round parts of plants which open up into flowers.
"were opening their flowers"

tn.ref: I was so happy that I felt I was riding in the chariot of a prince
tn.text: The lover uses this image to express how happy he is. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
"Come back, come back." This is repeated for emphasis.
look intently at something for a time

tn.ref: as if I were dancing between two rows of dancers
tn.text: It would be a wonderful thing to see the woman dancing with the other dancers. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_hypo]])
